page.title: 15A Walk in Lavenham Part 2
page.content: Near the Guildhall,an overhanging house has horizontal shutters,which show it was originally a Tudor shop.The pink house at the junction of Market Lane and High Street shows clearly the wooden pegs used to hold the timbers together.Pegging was done on the ground;on Raising Day,everyone helped to push the timbers into place. Marks of the props which held up the timbers can still be seen. A bishop's mitre is carved on the wall of the Swan Hotel. Bishop Blaise,patron saint of wool- traders,is said to have been martyred by having his flesh combed off. 7 Lady Street,a Tudor building with 17th century additions was once a shop and has a long room-the Solar-where the mistress of the house supervised her woolworkers.There is a fine example of a Crown or King Post-a collection of timber posts to hold up the roof.
